text: Groseclose Water Project
label: TITLE

text: Service Commencement for Groseclose Water Project
label: BODY

text: Marion, Virginia
label: BODY

text: April 8, 2005
label: BODY

text: Today I am pleased to join with Smyth County residents in celebrating the commencement of new public water service
label: BODY

text: for the communities of Groseclose and Atkins. This project represents another significant success in our ongoing work to
label: BODY

text: bring clean drinking water to all Southwest Virginia homes.
label: BODY

text: Beginning today, 62 homes in the communities of Groseclose and Atkins will for the first time receive publicly provided
label: BODY

text: drinking water. In the coming months, an additional 15 homes will also be added to the service area bringing the total
label: BODY

text: service area from the new water project to 77 homes in the Groseclose and Atkins communities. Previously, residents in
label: BODY

text: these communities had to rely on private wells for their drinking water, many of which were often insufficient. Residents in
label: BODY

text: the area have also endured on various occasions temporary boiling restrictions at their homes to ensure that the water
label: BODY

text: from the private wells was safe for drinking.
label: BODY

text: In addition to the 77 homes which are receiving the new public water service , the Mountain Empire Regional Airport and
label: BODY

text: five other businesses in the area will also have access to the new public water system, and today's celebration marks a
label: BODY

text: new opportunity for business and industrial development in Smyth County. Currently, the area from the Exit 54
label: BODY

text: interchange on Interstate 81 to the Wythe County line is underdeveloped. However, this area presents an outstanding
label: BODY

text: location for future residential, industrial and commercial growth due to its proximity to the Airport and Interstate 81. With
label: BODY

text: access to public drinking water now in place, I look forward to working with Smyth County officials in encouraging new
label: BODY

text: development of various kinds in the area which surrounds us today.
label: BODY

text: The new water system was supported with $661,906 in federal funds from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's
label: BODY

text: Safe Drinking Water Act program which is administered by the Virginia Department of Health. This sum represents the
label: BODY

text: entire cost of the water project.
label: BODY

text: More than three and one half miles of water lines have been constructed along Lee Highway from the Exit 54
label: BODY

text: interchange to the Wythe County line, along Rocky Hollow Road and along Nelson Lane. In addition, a pump station has
label: BODY

text: been constructed on Lee Highway to ensure adequate water pressure for the project.
label: BODY

text: The new public water service which will now be provided to residents of Groseclose and Atkins is a outstanding example
label: BODY

text: of the combined efforts of federal, state and local officials to establish safe and clean public drinking water for our
label: BODY

text: region's residents.
label: BODY

text: Congressman Rick Boucher
label: BODY

text: http://www.boucher.house.gov
label: BODY

text: Powered by Joomla!
label: BODY

text: Generated: 2 May, 2006, 18:55
label: BODY

text: Approximately 20 years ago, barely one-half of Smyth County residents had access to publicly provided drinking water.
label: BODY

text: Since that time, we have actively worked to obtain millions in federal funding to establish new water systems in Smyth
label: BODY

text: County, including more than $13 million in the past 10 years alone. Today, everyone here can proudly acknowledge that
label: BODY

text: this work on the part of many people has born fruit. Today, 72 percent of all Smyth County homes have access to
label: BODY

text: publicly funded water systems.
label: BODY

text: I would also like to take the opportunity of these remarks to comment on the next infrastructure project which we are
label: BODY

text: working to fund for the community of Groseclose. In December of 2004, Congress approved my request for a federal
label: BODY

text: appropriation in the amount of $250,000 to launch a public wastewater system project for Groseclose. Since that time,
label: BODY

text: additional federal funding in the amount of $346,871 from the Appalachian Regional Commission has been secured.
label: BODY

text: Smyth County is currently seeking additional funding from the Commonwealth of Virginia that will be necessary to
label: BODY

text: construct the new sewer system and hopes to begin construction on the project later this year.
label: BODY

text: Developing a reliable network of infrastructure for all residents of Smyth County is a task that involves the cooperation
label: BODY

text: and dedication of many individuals. And I want to thank some of those who have been instrumental in the success of the
label: BODY

text: Groseclose water project and for the work they continue to do to establish public wastewater service for the community.
label: BODY

text: I want to commend Charlie Clark who serves as Chairman of the Smyth County Board of Supervisors and Chairman of
label: BODY

text: the County's Water and Sewer Committee; Harold Slemp, Groseclose representative on the Board of Supervisors; other
label: BODY

text: Members of the Board; and Ed Whitmore, Smyth County Administrator; for all of their diligent work to advance the
label: BODY

text: expansion of Smyth County's water and wastewater systems. This project is another example of the good work they are
label: BODY

text: doing.
label: BODY

text: I also want to thank Scott Simpson, Smyth County Engineer, and Sally Morgan, the Community and Economic
label: BODY

text: Development Director for Smyth County, who both deserve recognition for their effective work in aid of this project.
label: BODY

text: I also want to thank Bob Dix and Elsie Evans for their commitment and dedication in bringing a public water system to the
label: BODY

text: community of Groseclose and the Mountain Empire Airport.
label: BODY

text: Finally, I want to thank my District Administrator, Laura Lee, and my new Project Manager, Courtney Lamie, for their
label: BODY

text: persistent and persuasive work in achieving this success. Their outstanding work has substantially contributed to the
label: BODY

text: success we celebrate today.
label: BODY

text: Today's ceremony is an example of what can be achieved when citizens and government officials at the local, state and
label: BODY

text: federal levels work together in aid of a common purpose. For that cooperation and successful work in providing for clean
label: BODY

text: and safe public drinking water for the residents of Groseclose and Atkins, I want to commend everyone here and offer
label: BODY

text: special congratulations to the residents and business owners who will be receiving this vital new service.
label: BODY

text: Congressman Rick Boucher
label: BODY
